channel.title: Joe Buhlig
channel.description: leverage the digital and welcome real life

item.title: 54: Work Clean by Dan Charnas
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Can the world of professional chefs teach us anything about productivity? Joe and Mike seem to agree with Dan Charnas and say, yes. Mis-en-place!
item.content:encoded: Can the world of professional chefs teach us anything about productivity? Joe and Mike seem to agree with Dan Charnas and say, yes. Mis-en-place!

item.title: 32: We Really Gotta Talk About Team Management
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: As Joe and Drew both grow their respective businesses, their usual task management talk transitions to a similar topic: team management. Drew gives the floor to Joe, who talks about why he manages projects and not people, and how to find the right system.
item.content:encoded: As Joe and Drew both grow their respective businesses, their usual task management talk transitions to a similar topic: team management. Drew gives the floor to Joe, who talks about why he manages projects and not people, and how to find the right system.

item.title: 53: Boundaries by Henry Cloud
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Should you set limits on what you’ll do with and for other people? And if so, what should those lines be? And do those limits have a place in the church?
item.content:encoded: Should you set limits on what you’ll do with and for other people? And if so, what should those lines be? And do those limits have a place in the church?

item.title: 31: A Brick and Mortar Space
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Drew bought a coffee shop. He tells the story, and talks about how it’s changing his productivity habits.
item.content:encoded: Drew bought a coffee shop. He tells the story, and talks about how it’s changing his productivity habits.

item.title: 52: The Power of Habit by Charles Duhigg
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Up to 40% of our daily actions are influenced by our habits, but how do you actually influence them? In this episode, Joe & Mike dive into The Power of Habit and discover the secret to lasting positive change.
item.content:encoded: Up to 40% of our daily actions are influenced by our habits, but how do you actually influence them? In this episode, Joe & Mike dive into The Power of Habit and discover the secret to lasting positive change.

item.title: 51: Great at Work by Morten Hansen
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: There is a myth in the workplace that says we need to work longer hours to achieve more and do so with higher quality. But this is purely a myth and there’s a lot of science to prove it.
item.content:encoded: There is a myth in the workplace that says we need to work longer hours to achieve more and do so with higher quality. But this is purely a myth and there’s a lot of science to prove it.

item.title: 30: Downtime Accountability Group
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Joe turns this episode into a confessional and makes a vulnerable statement: He’s a phone addict. Drew and Joe discuss our modern tendency to spend too much time on our devices, Joe reveals how he’s dealing with it, and Drew covers the ways that iOS 12 provides some ‘app limits’...
item.content:encoded: Joe turns this episode into a confessional and makes a vulnerable statement: He’s a phone addict. Drew and Joe discuss our modern tendency to spend too much time on our devices, Joe reveals how he’s dealing with it, and Drew covers the ways that iOS 12 provides some ‘app limits’ of its own. Since iOS 12 gets brought up, so too does the other looming Apple beta: Mojave.

item.title: 50: 2018 Bookworm Draft
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: If you listen to Bookworm as a way to filter your book list, then this episode will blow your mind. Joe and Mike pick their top ten books draft-style. They’re not necessarily Bookworm books either. Also included: a special surprise.
item.content:encoded: If you listen to Bookworm as a way to filter your book list, then this episode will blow your mind. Joe and Mike pick their top ten books draft-style. They’re not necessarily Bookworm books either. Also included: a special surprise.

item.title: 29: Back to a Digital Task Manager
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: An episode dedicated to a singular topic: Joe is back to using OmniFocus.
item.content:encoded: An episode dedicated to a singular topic: Joe is back to using OmniFocus.

item.title: 49: Peak by Anders Ericsson
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: What does it take to become the best? And what do the world’s greatest do that puts them at the top? And how does that translate into our day to day lives?
item.content:encoded: What does it take to become the best? And what do the world’s greatest do that puts them at the top? And how does that translate into our day to day lives?

item.title: 28: Move from One Phase to Another
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Drew talks about his new business venture, Keyhouse! After Joe introduced Procourse last week, this conversation continues the same dialogue on freelance work becoming something bigger.
item.content:encoded: Drew talks about his new business venture, Keyhouse! After Joe introduced Procourse last week, this conversation continues the same dialogue on freelance work becoming something bigger.

item.title: 27: The Whole Working on the Internet Dilemma
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Joe talks about his new business venture, ProCourse! This leads to a conversation about the natural evolution from freelancer to business owner, and all of the challenges that come with it: Setting goals (or choosing not to), getting buried in email, adding yet-another-Slack channel, and telling people IRL what you...
item.content:encoded: Joe talks about his new business venture, ProCourse! This leads to a conversation about the natural evolution from freelancer to business owner, and all of the challenges that come with it: Setting goals (or choosing not to), getting buried in email, adding yet-another-Slack channel, and telling people IRL what you do in the first place.

item.title: 48: How to Win Friends and Influence People by Dale Carnegie
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: It’s time for another classic that both Mike and Joe are a bit embarrassed they haven’t read previously. And it turns out to be a book where the title doesn’t do it justice.
item.content:encoded: It’s time for another classic that both Mike and Joe are a bit embarrassed they haven’t read previously. And it turns out to be a book where the title doesn’t do it justice.

item.title: 26: Now Somehow an Employer
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Joe transcends the typical mailbox and gets a UPS box of his own. This leads to a conversation about home offices, which leads to a conversation about wanting to appear legitimate, which leads to an unexpected conversation about learning how to take on new roles.
item.content:encoded: Joe transcends the typical mailbox and gets a UPS box of his own. This leads to a conversation about home offices, which leads to a conversation about wanting to appear legitimate, which leads to an unexpected conversation about learning how to take on new roles.

item.title: 47: The Three Big Questions for a Frantic Family by Patrick Lencioni
item.dc:creator: joe_buhlig
item.description: Should you think about your family in the same way you think about an organization? And what are the ramifications of the answer to that question?
item.content:encoded: Should you think about your family in the same way you think about an organization? And what are the ramifications of the answer to that question?
